2. you don't increase the current capacity counter. Meaning you don't care about capacity in this case, because the key already existed and you are just updating. Except you aren't just updating it, but you are also changing key's order in the structure (above point 1.)
Why are we using doubly linked list instead of single linked list?\nWe are not moving backwards?\n
[@user4796V](/user4796V) Maybe but it would appear to have a space penalty compared to just adding an extra node pointer to a node.
[@psionl0](/psionl0) you can create another hash map that maintain the key for the node (of a sll ) and the the node that appears before

To remove a node from a SL list, you have to follow the links from the head to the node in question which makes it an O(N) operation and since get and put both involve moving nodes to the head of the list, you will get TLE.\n\nBut a node in a DL list can remove itself without the need to follow links so it is an O(1) operation.

Design a data structure that follows the constraints of a Least Recently Used (LRU) cache.

Implement the LRUCache class:

LRUCache(int capacity) Initialize the LRU cache with positive size capacity.
int get(int key) Return the value of the key if the key exists, otherwise return -1.
void put(int key, int value) Update the value of the key if the key exists. Otherwise, add the key-value pair to the cache. If the number of keys exceeds the capacity from this operation, evict the least recently used key.
The functions get and put must each run in O(1) average time complexity.
Both get and put calls should update the cache.

Incorrect unit test

["LRUCache","get","put","get","put","put","get","get"]
[[2],[2],[2,6],[1],[1,5],[1,2],[1],[2]]
Expected:
[null,-1,null,-1,null,null,2,6]
Should be:
[null,-1,null,-1,null,null,2,-1]

After putting {1,5} into the cache we end up with having two pairs in the cache
{2,6}, {1,5}

Now we need to add {1,2}
Which one to remove ? Both were never used.
Ofc {2,6}. Why would we keep oldest pair in our cache ?

But the leetcode algorithm removes {1,5} , which does not make any sense.

Leetcode pls fix it.

- why Doubly linked list: insert and remove needs be O(1).

The description is misleading - quoting:
"The functions get and put must each run in O(1) average time complexity."

Note that "O(1)" means "worst case complexity",
while "Theta(1)" is "average case complexity".

Solving this question as described is *impossible* in today's software technology.
Read more here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation#Family_of_Bachmann%E2%80%93Landau_notations

If we have pairs with the same key in the cache, like {2=1,2=2} which value should get(2) for example return?
You shouldn\'t have that. It suggests that you added another case with the same key when you should have updated the existing key.

This is the type of question that should be asked in an interview. There\'s no trick and requires minimum prior knowledge. It well reflects the candidate\'s ability of implementing their own thoughts. Be able to implement an idea is the most important thing in real work. Algorithms can be googled.
https://youtu.be/61i-qpZSfyg
https://youtu.be/8N_L_c71avU

For me designing the LRU Cache was not intuitive. 
- why Doubly linked list: insert and remove needs be O(1).
 - After I got started with implementation, understood it has to be circular doubly linked list. Thats how we can remove the Least Recently Used key, value node(tail of doubly linked list) in O(1) time.

What is recommended solution for LRU Cache during interview ? using LinkedHashMap or Doubly linked list? Doubly linked list is much lengthy code and requires practice. Can I write solution usingLinkedHashMap and explain the approach using doubly linked list if needed?
So one part that seems to be hard to read, is that the \'get\' operation is using the key, but is the \'put\' operation using the key? Is this different for whether the key already exists or not?.

The description is misleading - quoting:
"The functions get and put must each run in O(1) average time complexity."

Note that "O(1)" means "worst case complexity",
while "Theta(1)" is "average case complexity".

Solving this question as described is *impossible* in today's software technology.
Read more here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation#Family_of_Bachmann%E2%80%93Landau_notations

I think '2' and '5' can also be looked as "Strobogrammatic Number"
'1' and '8' are not even exactly Strobogrammatic if you want it to look perfectly rotationally symmetric .
Wikipedia thinks '2' is Strobogrammatic.
It really depends on how you define it. This is not a hard question, just please clarify it in the description.

I was confused too. I also forgot that 0 is also a valid number. Though, I think it\'s good to not have everything in the problem description because it\'ll make us better at thinking edge cases ourself because for 2 and 5 I ran a test case and it return false. Kind of like asking the interviewer.
For those annoyed with the lack of clarity, the strobogrammatic numbers are 0, 1, and 8 on their own. The pair of 6 and 9 are counted.

I'm using a digital clock, and when I turn 629 upside down, it's the same.
Both 2 and 5 are strobogrammatic with themselves
555 = 555
2605092 = 2605092

Assume we are "rotating" on the z-axis
And digital numbers are close enough

I did a test of 629 and got "expected false"
This question is example that on interview better ask details before realisation. Or perform test for cases with 2, 5 and 1 before submit.

def is_strobogrammatic(num)
      num == num.tr("6923457", "96").reverse
    end

Based on [AsianHippo's solution](https://leetcode.com/discuss/85661/java-solution-by-comparing-the-reverse-string).
The OJ does not consider a corner case that the input is "00"
How is "1" or "11" strobo, but "10" or "18" are not?

What if the size is too big to hold in memory?

Given a stream of integers and a window size, calculate the moving average of all integers in the sliding window.

so here is how to read this question: 
init an object, with a function "next" which gets a value and return the average of all last "window size"# previuse nembers given to "next" before.
for example, let 3 be the window size.
calling next(1) will return the ave of 1 which is 1
calling next(3) will return (3+1)/2
calling next(1) will return (1+3+1)/3
calling next(2) will return (2+1+3)/3  ** we dropped the first 1 as we are limited to 3 values of "window size"

Issue with LeetCode - multiple submissions of same solution is giving different runtimes.\n\nI have submitted the same solution 2-3 times. Sometimes it gives 72ms runtime, and sometimes it gives 40ms runtime. Even though I have not touched the code in both cases. :(
Running to an issue preventing me from getting the right answer. Despite outputting a float, it will truncate my decimal once I return it. Anyone else running into this?
